Section.Description: A chemical formula is a way of expressing information about the proportions of atoms that constitute a particular chemical compound, using a single line of chemical element symbols and numbers. PubChem uses the Hill system, whereby the number of carbon atoms in a molecule is indicated first, the number of hydrogen atoms second, and then the number of all other chemical elements in alphabetical order. When the formula contains no carbon, all the elements, including hydrogen, are listed alphabetically. Sources other than PubChem may include a variant of the formula that is more structural or natural to chemists, for example, H2SO4 for sulfuric acid, rather than the Hill version H2O4S.

A CAS Registry Number (also called CAS RN or CAS Number) is a proprietary registry number assigned by the Chemical Abstracts Service (CAS) division of the American Chemical Society (ACS).  It is a numeric identifier that can contain up to 10 digits, divided by hyphens into three parts.

The European Community (EC) number is a seven-digit identifier assigned by the European Chemicals Agency (ECHA) to substances for regulatory purposes within the European Union. EC numbers are sometimes referred to as EINECS, ELINCS, or NLP numbers, because the EC Inventory comprises three individual inventories (EINECS, ELINCS, and the NLP list).

Molecular weight or molecular mass refers to the mass of a molecule. It is calculated as the sum of the mass of each constituent atom multiplied by the number of atoms of that element in the molecular formula.  The molecular weight is also called the relative molar mass, because molecular weights are reported in daltons, which is defined relative to the mass of the isotope 12C (carbon 12).

Section.Description: The topological polar surface area (TPSA) is an estimate of the polar surface area (in Angstroms^2) of a molecule, computed as the surface sum over polar atoms in the molecule.  The implementation follows the paper by Ertl et al. [J. Med. Chem. 2000, 43, 3714-3717]: only N and O are considered, 3D coordinates are not used, and there are various precomputed factors for different hybridizations, charges and participation in aromatic systems.

Section.Description: Isotope atom count is the number of isotopes that are not most abundant for the corresponding chemical elements. For example, among three isotopes of carbon (i.e., C-12, C-13, and C-14), the isotope atom count considers the C-13 and C-14 atoms, because C-12 is the most abundant isotope of carbon.

Reference: Computed by PubChem

Section.Description: An atom stereocenter, also known as a chiral center, is an atom that is attached to four different types of atoms (or groups of atoms) in the tetrahedral arrangement. It can have either (R)- or (S)- configurations.  Some compounds, such as racemic mixtures, have an undefined atom stereocenter, whose (R/S)-configuration is not specifically defined.  The "defined atom stereocenter count" is the number of atom stereocenters whose configurations are specifically defined.

Section.Description: The density of a gas or vapor relative to that of the reference gas.  While some resources use the hydrogen gas as the reference gas for the vapor density calculation, many resources (particularly in relation to safety considerations at commercial and industrial facilities in the U.S.) defines the vapor density with respect to the density of air, which has an arbitrary value of one.  If a gas has a vapor density of less than one it will generally rise in air. If the vapor density is greater than one the gas will generally sink in air.

For ingestion, rinse mouth and administer 5 mL/kg up to 200 mL of water for dilution if the patient can swallow, has a strong gag reflex, and does not drool. Section.Description: This section provides information to evaluate the environmental impact of the chemical if it were released to the environment. The information may include data from toxicity tests performed on aquatic and/or terrestrial organisms, where available (e.g., acute or chronic aquatic toxicity data for fish, algae, and crustaceans; toxicity data on birds, bees, and plants).  This section also includes information on whether there is a potential for the chemical to persist or degrade in the environment either through biodegradation or other processes (such as oxidation or hydrolysis) as well as the concentration or amount of the chemical found in the environment (e.g., in plants, animals as well as in the atmosphere or water).

This section summarizes the environmental fate/exposure of this chemical, including the natural and artificial sources of the chemical as a pollutant, its environmental fate, biodegradation, abiotic degradation, bioconcentration, etc.

StringWithMarkup.String: p-Cresyl diphenyl phosphate's production and use as an additive for plasticizers and gasoline, as a flame retardant, and use in lubricants, hydraulic fluids and food packaging may result in its release to the environment through various waste streams. It probably is seldom a pure compound, but rather a mixture of o-, m-, and p-cresyl and phenyl phosphates. If released to air, an estimated vapor pressure of 1.0X10-6 mm Hg at 25 °C indicates p-cresyl diphenyl phosphate will exist in both the vapor and particulate phases in the atmosphere. Vapor-phase p-cresyl diphenyl phosphate will be degraded in the atmosphere by reaction with photochemically-produced hydroxyl radicals; the half-life for this reaction in air is estimated to be 1.2 days. Particulate-phase p-cresyl diphenyl phosphate will be removed from the atmosphere by wet and dry deposition. Based on a reported direct photolysis half-life of 4.86 years in aqueous solution for the isomeric mixture, direct photolysis is not expected to be an important fate process. If released to soil, p-cresyl diphenyl phosphate is expected to have no mobility based upon an estimated Koc of 1.8X10+4. Volatilization from moist soil surfaces is not expected to be an important fate process based upon an estimated Henry's Law constant of 1.0X10-7 atm-cu m/mole. p-Cresyl diphenyl phosphate is not expected to volatilize from dry soil surfaces based upon its vapor pressure. Biodegradation in soil or in water is expected to be an important environmental fate process based upon observed biodegradability in river and lake water of isomeric mixtures of cresyl diphenyl phosphate. Aqueous hydrolysis will contribute to soil degradation in moist alkaline soil. If released into water, p-cresyl diphenyl phosphate is expected to adsorb to suspended solids and sediment based upon the estimated Koc. Volatilization from water surfaces is not expected to be an important fate process based upon this compound's estimated Henry's Law constant. An observed BCF range of 110 to 1420 for similar triaryl phosphates suggests bioconcentration in aquatic organisms is high to very high. Reported hydrolysis half-lives of 47 days at pH 7 and 5.1 days at pH 9 at 25 °C indicate hydrolysis is expected to contribute to degradation water, especially in alkaline water. Occupational exposure to p-cresyl diphenyl phosphate (as part of the commercial isomeric mixture) may occur through inhalation and dermal contact with this compound at workplaces where p-cresyl diphenyl phosphate is produced or used. The general population can be exposed via dermal contact with consumer products containing p-cresyl diphenyl phosphate. (SRC)

StringWithMarkup.String: TERRESTRIAL FATE: Based on a classification scheme(1), an estimated Koc value of 1.8X10+4(SRC), determined from a structure estimation method(2), indicates that p-cresyl diphenyl phosphate is expected to be immobile in soil(SRC). Volatilization of p-cresyl diphenyl phosphate from moist soil surfaces is not expected to be an important fate process(SRC) given an estimated Henry's Law constant of 1.0X10-7 atm-cu m/mole(SRC), using a fragment constant estimation method(3). p-Cresyl diphenyl phosphate is not expected to volatilize from dry soil surfaces based on an estimated vapor pressure of 1.0X10-6 mm Hg at 25 °C(SRC), determined from a fragment constant method(2). Biodegradation of p-cresyl diphenyl phosphate in soil is expected to be an important fate process(SRC), based on rapid biodegradation of cresyl diphenyl phosphate mixtures in river and lake water die-away tests (half-lives on the order of several days or less and complete degradation within a week)(3,4). An observed CO2 evolution of 53.2% in 7 days using an activated sludge inoculum also suggests biodegradability(3). Based on reported aqueous hydrolysis half-lives of 47 days at pH 7 and 5.1 days at pH 9(5), hydrolysis is expected to contribute to soil degradation, especially in moist alkaline soil(SRC).

Reference: (1) Swann RL et al; Res Rev 85: 23 (1983)

StringWithMarkup.String: AQUATIC FATE: Based on a recommended classification scheme(1), an estimated Koc value of 1.8X10+4(SRC), determined from a structure estimation method(2), indicates that p-cresyl diphenyl phosphate is expected to adsorb to suspended solids and sediment in water(SRC). Volatilization from water surfaces is not expected(3) based upon an estimated Henry's Law constant of 1.0X10-7 atm-cu m/mole(SRC), developed using a fragment constant estimation method(2). According to a classification scheme(4), an observed BCF range of 110 to 1,420 in fish for similar triaryl phosphates(5,6) suggests bioconcentration of p-cresyl diphenyl phosphate in aquatic organisms is high to very high(SRC). Biodegradation of p-cresyl diphenyl phosphate in natural water is expected to be an important fate process(SRC), based on rapid biodegradation of cresyl diphenyl phosphate mixtures in river and lake water die-away tests (half-lives on the order of several days or less and complete degradation within a week)(7,8). An observed CO2 evolution of 53.2% in 7 days using an activated sludge inoculum also suggests biodegradability(7). Based on reported aqueous hydrolysis half-lives of 47 days at pH 7 and 5.1 days at pH 9 at 25 °C for cresyl diphenyl phosphate mixtures(9), hydrolysis is expected to contribute to degradation in water, especially in alkaline water(SRC).

StringWithMarkup.String: ATMOSPHERIC FATE: According to a model of gas/particle partitioning of semivolatile organic compounds in the atmosphere(1), p-cresyl diphenyl phosphate, which has an estimated vapor pressure of 1.0X10-6 mm Hg at 25 °C(SRC), determined from a fragment constant method(2), will exist in both the vapor and particulate phases in the ambient atmosphere. Vapor-phase p-cresyl diphenyl phosphate is degraded in the atmosphere by reaction with photochemically-produced hydroxyl radicals(SRC); the half-life for this reaction in air is estimated to be 1.4 days(SRC), calculated from its rate constant of 1.2X10-11 cu cm/molecule-sec at 25 °C(SRC) that was derived using a structure estimation method(2). Particulate-phase p-cresyl diphenyl  phosphate may be removed from the air by wet and dry deposition(SRC). Based on a reported direct photolysis half-life of 4.86 years for the isomeric cresyl diphenyl phosphate mixture in aqueous solution(3), direct photolysis is not expected to be an important fate process(SRC).

Section.Description: This section provides information on environmental biodegradation for this compound. Biodegradation is the breakdown of organic matter by microorganisms, such as bacteria and fungi.  An important measure of biodegradability of wastewater is the biochemical oxygen demand (BOD), which is the amount of dissolved oxygen (DO) needed (i.e. demanded) by aerobic biological organisms to break down organic material present in a given water sample at certain temperature over a specific time period.

Reference: (1) Saeger VW et al; Environ Sci Technol 13: 840-4 (1979)
(2) Howard PH, Deo PG; Bull Environ Contam Toxicol 22: 337-44 (1979)

StringWithMarkup.String: AEROBIC: Using a semi-continuous activated sludge test and a 22-week test duration, influent  concentrations of 3 mg/L/day cresyl diphenyl phosphate (isomeric mixture) were biodegraded (primary biodegradation) by 82%(1). In CO2 evolution tests using activated sludge, cresyl diphenyl phosphate (iosmeric mixture, concentration of 23.1 mg/L) exhibited theoretical CO2 evolution of 53.2, 84.5 and 91.3% after 7, 28 and 48 days respectively(1). In a river water die-away test, cresyl diphenyl phosphate (isomeric mixture) was about 50% biodegraded after 3 days and completely degraded in 4 days(1). A die-away study using Lake Ontario water from Oswego, NY found that commercial plasticizers containing p-cresyl diphenyl phosphate exhibited a two-day lag period before degrading rapidly with complete degradation within 7 days(2).

Section.Description: Abiotic degradation is a process by which a chemical substance is broken down into smaller molecules by non-biotic means (e.g., hydrolysis, photolysis, and oxidation).

Reference: (1) US EPA; Estimation Program Interface (EPI) Suite. Ver. 4.10. Jan, 2011. Available from, as of Oct 11, 2012: https://www.epa.gov/oppt/exposure/pubs/episuitedl.htm

(2) OECD; OECD SIDS (Screening Information Data Set), Diphenyl Cresyl Phosphate, CAS No. 26444-49-5, UNEP (United Nations Environment Programme) Publications, 1998; available Online as of Oct 11, 2012: https://www.inchem.org/documents/sids/sids/26444495.pdf

StringWithMarkup.String: The rate constant for the vapor-phase reaction of p-cresyl diphenyl phosphate with photochemically-produced hydroxyl radicals has been estimated as 1.2X10-11 cu cm/molecule-sec at 25 °C(SRC) using a structure estimation method(1). This corresponds to an atmospheric half-life of about 1.4 days at an atmospheric concentration of 5X10+5 hydroxyl radicals per cu cm(1). Using OECD test guideline 111 (25 °C), the aqueous hydrolysis half-life of cresyl diphenyl phosphate (isomeric mixture) was found to be 47 days at pH 7 and 5.1 days at pH 9(2); cresyl diphenyl phosphate was stable at pH 4(2); hydrolysis of p-cresyl diphenyl phosphate is expected to be similar(SRC). Photodegradation tests of diphenyl cresyl phosphate (isomeric mixture) in aqueous solution determined a direct photolysis half-life of 4.86 years(2); therefore, direct photolysis is not expected to be an important fate process for p-cresyl diphenyl phosphate(SRC).

Section.Description: This section provides information on environmental bioconcentration for this compound.  Bioconcentration is the accumulation of a chemical in or on an organism when the source of chemical is solely water. Bioconcentration is a term that was created for use in the field of aquatic toxicology. Bioconcentration can also be defined as the process by which a chemical concentration in an aquatic organism exceeds that in water as a result of exposure to a waterborne chemical.

Reference: (1) Muir DCG; in The Handbook of Environmental Chemistry; Anthropogenic Substances German: Springer-Berlag Berlin 3: 41-66  1984)
(2) Boethling RS, Cooper JC; Res Rev 94: 49-99 (1985)
(3) Franke C et al; Chemosphere 29: 1501-14 (1994)

StringWithMarkup.String: An observed BCF range of 110 to 1,420 has been reported in rainbow trout, fathead minnow, killfish and bluegill fish for triphenyl phosphate and tricresyl phosphate(1,2); p-cresyl diphenyl phosphate is expected to have similar BCF values(SRC). According to a classification scheme(3), a BCF range of 110 to 1,420 suggests bioconcentration in aquatic organisms is high to very high(SRC). Depuration half-lives of triphenyl and tricresyl phosphates range from 4 to 6 days(6) indicating that p-cresyl diphenyl phosphate is expected to rapidly decrease in concentration when aquatic organisms are removed from contaminated water(SRC).

Section.Description: Sorption to soils and sediments is an important factor on the transport and fate of organic contaminants in the environment.  The soil/water adsorption coefficient, also known as solid-water distribution coefficient (Kd), measures the amount of chemical substance adsorbed onto soil per amount of water.  Since adsorption occurs predominantly by partition into the soil organic matter, it is more useful to normalize the Kd value to the organic carbon content of a soil and express the distribution coefficient in Koc (organic carbon normalized distribution coefficient).  The greater the Kd (or Koc) value, the less likely a chemical will leach or contribute to runoff.  A very high value means it is strongly adsorbed onto soil and organic matter and does not move throughout the soil.

Reference: (1) US EPA; Estimation Program Interface (EPI) Suite. Ver. 4.10. Jan, 2011. Available from, as of Oct 11, 2012: https://www.epa.gov/oppt/exposure/pubs/episuitedl.htm
(2) Swann RL et al; Res Rev 85: 17-28 (1983)

According to a classification scheme(2), this estimated Koc value suggests that p-cresyl diphenyl phosphate is expected to be immobile in soil.

Reference.Name: MolGenie Organic Chemistry Ontology
Reference.Description: An organic chemistry ontology developed by MolGenie and OntoChem to assign chemical entities to structural classes, split into three main subsections: calculated properties, compounds and substructural concepts. The ontology contains chemistry structural classes with a focus on elements and small organic compounds, but not inorganic, polymer, biopolymer, metal complexes, metal organic frameworks (MOFs) and other chemistry entities. The ontology has been mapped to several collections of chemicals, including (a) Chemicals of Biological Interest (ChEBI), (b) the ChEMBL database of bioactive molecules, (c) the LOTUS natural product collection, (d) per- and polyfluoroalkyl substances (PFAS) extracted from Barnabas et al (2022) DOI: 10.1039/D2DD00019A (e) PubChemLite and (f) the ZeroPM Global Chemical Inventory.
